PiS got 39%
CP got 23%
KuK got 9%
Now got 7%
PPP got 5%
and 17% went to parties that didn't make the threshold. here's how I crunch the numbers using the d'hondt system
PiS ends up with 47%  NOT A MAJORITY
CP with 28%
KuK with 11%
Now with 8%
PPP with 9% So, I don't understand why Politico--and EVERYBODY ELSE--says PiS could end up with more than a majority of seats.  I wonder if there's another element in this that causes seats to not directly correlate with % (??).  Since this question asks about SEATS, not %, I guess I should go with the experts. There must be something I don't understand/know.
Maybe the exit polls will end up being wrong, but I'm not holding my breath they'll be wrong enough.

Poland has a long history with the USSR and they haven't forgotten the price they payed to be free of it.  The effect of the immigrant crisis on the attitudes of the Polish people may impact the election.  If Russia takes the rest of the Ukraine there will no doubt be those that my feel it is safer to be a friend of a close threat than an ally of a distant friend.

http://www.politico.eu/article/polands-government-defeated-in-parliamentary-elections-2/ "The official results will be released on Tuesday. In previous elections, Polish exit polls have not always been accurate. There is a chance that some of the smaller parties balancing on the edge of the 5 percent threshold needed to enter parliament, could still squeeze in.
. . . 
The preliminary results imply that PiS will get 242 seats in the 460-member parliament, enough for an absolute majority.

The parliamentary election, Poland appears to join the region’s rightward drift toward nationalism and toss out the center-right party that has governed the country for eight years. Beata Szydlo, the Law and Justice Party’s candidate for prime minister, has campaigned against being forced by the European Union to accept a set number of the refugees who have been flooding into Europe. Polls show the Law and Justice Party leading the governing Civic Platform Party, whose candidate for prime minister is the incumbent, Ewa Kopacz. But if it does not win by a wide enough margin, it may need to form a coalition government. Poland, to the unhappy surprise of several of its allies in the region, decided to go along with Germany and other Western nations in approving the quotas on Tuesday, despite strong resistance from Polish voters and a bitter parliamentary campaign in which the longtime governing party, Civic Platform, is highly vulnerable.

COMMENT:  A plurality seems to be assured.  The question is if PiS will get a majority.  The most optimistic poll says it'll get 40%; can 40% translate into a majority of seats?
The weather forecast is looking dry which could work in PiS favour given their core voters. Hence I am notching up for a majority.

In Turkeys question it is noted that "he Justice and Development Party (AKP) failed to win a single-party majority in June's general election for the first time since 2002. After negotiations aimed at forming a coalition government collapsed, snap elections have been scheduled ". So the main party lost, and coalition failed. This again suggests change in this part of the world (though again note in the UK we re-elected the incumbents, but much more strongly from a coalition to outright). the "omens" suggest to me that this "energy" will be reflected in Poland for a majority. Coalition governments are the norm in Poland; while current opinion polls attribute the % share of vote to PiS in the high 30s (and in some cases even the low 40s), on the basis of past elections, this is unlikely to be sufficient to give them an outright majority in their own right.  - eg at the last Sejm election in 2011  the leading party, PO, got over 39% of the votes cast, but were still 23 seats short of a majority. In the election before that, in 2007, PiS got a higher percentage still - similar to the most favourable figures for them  given by the opinion polls at present - of 41.5%, but were still 21 seats short of a majority. Main argument in favour of PiS unprecedently getting a majority in their own right?  The main (liberal-conservative) opposition party PO appears weaker (according to opinion polls) than was the case in 2011 or 2007, while the remainder of the opposition (including the left-liberal and secularist parts are if anything more divided than in recent years, and also incorporate more new parties or formations than was the case in 2011 - a realignment of forces, and new subdivisions, seems to be underway - which could potentially weaken the already fairly weak position of the left. (It is not immediately obvious that the more reactionary-conservative PiS would benefit rather than the liberal-conservative PO though.) Second argument against: the recent trend, seen in several countries (most notably Israel and the UK) of opinion polls understating the support for right-wing or conservative parties. I am not however convinced this necessarily applies to anything like the same extent in present-day Poland  as in those generally more liberal societies.

PO holds a consistently Center Right position while PIS maintains a variance in the spectrum from Center Right to Center Left.  While it is likely that PO could maintain dominance in an election, it is unlikely to overcome the lead that PIS holds in the polls.  A plurality is the most likely outcome in the October 25, 2015 election.

The Polish system of seat allocation is more complicated than I thought. It seems seats are allocated by constituency (see http://www.sejm.gov.pl/english/sejm/pos.htm and http://www.nsd.uib.no/european_election_database/country/poland/parliamentary_elections.html; see the 41 Polish constituencies here: http://wybory2007.pkw.gov.pl/SJM/EN/WYN/M/1.htm) and not by the vote percentage obtained nationwide. That adds another level of uncertainty in forecasting a PiS majority vs. plurality. Ideally, one would need an accurate poll for each constituency to post an accurate forecast. Looking at the nationwide vote percentages won by the top two parties for each election from 1997-2011 and comparing that to the number of seats those parties they were allocated in the Sehm, I estimate that every percentage point a party receives in the national vote equals roughly 5.4 seats in the Sehm. That's just an average. The PiS once got 5.74 seats for each point it received in the national popular vote. Another party got as few as 5.04 seats for every percentage point. So, PiS should be able to win a majority of seats with only 43%-44% of the national popular vote. Over the last month, they have been polling at 35%-46.9%, probably averaging in the high 30s (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Polish_parliamentary_election,_2015). What happens if several parties hovering around the 5% threshold (8% threshold for the United Left coalition) fail to meet the threshold? What happens to their votes? Would that bump up PiS's vote percentage several points? And wouldn't that make a majority more plausible, even likely?

I live in Poland, so I may offer you a bit of insight into local politics. First of all, in Poland seats are allocated according to D'Hondt method.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/D'Hondt_method There are 460 seats in Poland's Sejm, so you (obviously) need 231 seats for Majority. Another - and MOST CRUCIAL - thing that we have to remember is that the election threshold in Poland in 5% This time everything depends on small parties - specifically whether or not they will cross the threshold. Currently there are 4 (!) parties that are on the verge of crossing the threshold and they account for MOST OF THE UNCERTAINTY in this question. Those parties are:
- KORWiN - extreme laissez faire when it comes to economy, far right when it comes to politics
- Kukiz's Movement - it's leader is a hell of a loose canon and at the same moment the only thing that keeps his 'party' in one piece.
- NPL - PO (Civic Platform) offshoot - this is strictly political plot to get votes of people dissatisfied with PO, but who won't vote on other parties.
- PSL - farmer's party, mostly interested in putting it's members and their relatives on well paid state sinecures and allocating as much money as they can on agricultural subsidies (they are farmers themselves after all...) Now, there is also SLD+TR lefty list, but they will most likely cross the threshold as they're the only left parties in Poland. Civic Platform itself is at stable 25% - that's their core electorate, so the support most likely will not fall below that. PIS support is at 38% and is not likely to change much in either way. NPL (and most likely SLD+TR) will ally with PO. Even if not, they WILL NOT form coalition with PIS. PSL will ally with whoever gives them better terms. KORWiN - most likely will stay in opposition, however alliance both with PO and PIS is possible, although highly unlikely. Kukiz - the same as above (KORWiN), however the alliance is even less likely. As far as the last two (KORWiN, Kukiz) are considered - the alliance may be formed, however it won't last long. Although this will satisfy question's resolution criteria. Possible scenarios. 1. If all of the small parties are left out - PIS will have majority. Highly unlikely 2. If one of the small parties gets in - PIS can steal a few of it's (or even PO!) MPs (Members of Parliament) to get majority. Even if this party is NPL, PIS may get away with getting majority. Still unlikely. 3. Two of the small parties get in - this scenario is quite possible. Now things start to get interesting.
PIS will not have Majority. It will have to form coalition with one of the small parties.
If one of those parties is PSL, PIS will be good. However it will be for example NPL+Kukiz or NPL+KORWiN, then PIS will have a problem and will have to make sacrifices in order to reach compromise and form coalition. 4. Three of the small parties get in - also quite possible. Basically (because of D'Hondt method) not much changes for PIS, however more work will be needed to form coalition. Possibility of wide PO+NPL+SLD+TR+ someoneelse coalition becomes a possibility. 5. All of the small parties get in. Things turn ugly for PIS - and Poland as such government would not be stable, unless some shifts on the political scene are made (party merging etc.).
PIS needs to get TWO small parties on board to form ruling coalition. Lots of sacrifices will have to be made.
At the same moment wide PO+someothers coalition looks increasingly more likely. Summary Probality of scenarion (from lowest to highest All of small left out.

The average of the final week's polls was 26.5%, well short of his actual first-round vote (34.8%). Could we see another opinion poll failure this time? I have PiS at 39.8% by calculating the unweighted average of all the polls listed in Wikipedia since August 20 (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Polish_parliamentary_election,_2015). A majority is not a stretch if we factor in the parties that might not reach the 5% threshold (8% for coalitions) for representation in the Sejm. Again, I took the unweighted average of the last 7 polls. 2.5% Coalition for the Renewal of Peace and Hope (5% threshold)
5% Modern Poland (5% threshold)
6.3 Kukiz' Movement (5% threshold)
9% United Left (8% threshold) Other minor parties have a combined average of 7.3% So, if the polls underestimate the level of support for PiS to the same extent as the presidential election (8.3%) AND a few of these parties fail to reach the threshold, we could see a PiS majority. In the final analysis, a PiS majority government would be shocking but not out of the question.
